title: Inside Baby2Baby's response to California's devastating wildfires | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: [Music]
[Music]
Hey folks, Jeff Berman here. This week
we're sharing my conversation with the
incredibly impressive co-CEOs of the
notfor-profit Baby TOB.
From day one of the devastating
wildfires in Los Angeles at the start of
the year, Baby Toby was on the ground
providing essential items to families in
dire need. Disaster relief is just part
of the support that Baby Toby provides
under Norah Weinstein and Kelly Sawyer
Patrick's leadership. In partnership
with not forprofits around the country,
they've now distributed more than 250
million diapers and they now serve over
a million families across the United
States each and every year. We gathered
recently for a Masters of Scale live
event in Los Angeles presented by our
partners at Capital 1 Business to talk
about how Kelly and Nora have scaled
baby to baby and what it was like to
face a disaster in their home town.
This is Masters of Scale.
Kelly, Nora, welcome to Masters of
Scale. I can't imagine a more fitting
and important conversation for us to
have um on this stage in LA. Um
uh I've been here for 20 years in LA.
It's home for me. Um, and the fires that
we had at the top of the year were
devastating for I'm sure everyone in the
room if you weren't personally affected,
someone you could love, some member of
your family, um, lost their home, lost
their business, lost their community.
Um, and so I want to take us back to
January 7th. Um, where where was each of
you when you when you first heard about

the fires? Where were you?
 You know, it
the news obviously started unfolding
slowly. So it was I was talking to
colleagues. I had friends calling. I
live in Brentwood. So I had like my
first batch of Palisades people texting
me. Then we were some not you know it
was kind of slowly trickling in. And um
it you know we've babyto baby has now
responded to a hundred disasters but
this one was different because this was
our backyard. It was our home. So, while
we're used to saying, "Okay, everyone,
we're having a huddle, there's a
hurricane, or this is hitting Texas or
this is happening in Florida, this was
um the manager of our warehouse has now
just been evacuated, or I was figuring
out where my kids were in school and
finding out what was happening." So, it
was so personal from the get-go.
And you we had to kind of juggle dealing
with the personal and dealing with the
professional, which was our jobs in this
moment were to take what we had learned
in 14 years and apply it where we're
looking out for children and families in
disasters and apply all the lessons
we've learned into this moment where it
probably mattered the most.
Kelly, where were you? I was sadly in
bed with the flu and you know, we're
watching each of our employees be
evacuated. One of our employees lost
their home. Their sister lost their
home. They evacuated with their children
with just the clothes on their back. So,
we were really in it in a way we'd never
been in it before. That felt so
different to us and personal to us
because all around us, not only friends
were losing their homes, but also our
staff who we care so much about. And
what was so amazing was that the
community came together and baby to baby
became this kind of like hub of like
what can we do? How can we help? We've
never had like volunteer sessions so
full people like beating down our doors
to come and there were hundreds of
people multiple times a day coming and
wanting to help. And many of the people

who came had lost their own homes
 and
they just you know would cry and say
like I want to do something. I don't
know what else to do. I just want to
help. And so people are putting together
fire relief packages for children and um
you know families who've lost
everything. And it was so scary and sad
but also so inspiring to see LA and the
community come together in that moment
and to have the space to be able to hold

that.
 So h how did you flip from we've
got to deal with ourselves and our
people to we've got to serve the
community. What how did you transition
into that mode? I feel like we have seen
it before because through our disaster
relief work, we're constantly around
people in these other cities who are
having similar circumstances. We know
that we are our team over 14 years has
built this expertise and we've built it
in 50 states and 300 cities. But in Los
Angeles, our team knows this city, every
inch of it. And we know where children
are and we know where the most

vulnerable children are.
 How do you
know? How how do you know that? I mean,
yes, you're you're you're Angelinos,
your staples of this community, you're
integrated, but is there data telling
you that? Is it because you've got
partners? Where's that coming from?
Right. It's because 14 years ago when
the two of us uh took over the
leadership of Babyto Baby and built what
what baby to baby is today,
we started off we we've always been a
model where we don't serve families and
children directly on a regular basis.
We've always known that in order to
scale, we had to serve partners, serve
their serve clients. So what that means
is we've been building for 14 years a
network of organizations in Los Angeles
and all over the country. So speaking
about Los Angeles, we have a program
team that is working with hospitals,
foster care agencies, homeless shelters,
schools,
community resource centers, and one by
one we onboarded them to serve them on a
regular basis. So that we might have a
tiny homeless shelter in the valley and
they have eight beds and we know that
regularly they need supplies for the
rotating eight families that might be
coming in and out. Then we also serve
the entire Los Angeles Unified School
District um where we're serving tens of
thousands of students who go to school
and they're identifying who the students
are who are most in need, who are
experiencing homelessness, who might be
um in foster care, etc. We know which
shelters to be looking out for to think,
well, that shelter must have burned
down, so we need to get to these kids
and they probably would have gone here.
where we know the principal at this
school, so we're gonna know who to

contact. So, that's what I mean.
 Kelly,
um, just staying with January for a
moment, um, help us understand the the
scope and scale of what the relief
efforts required and and the the the
size of what baby to baby did in in that

moment.
 I think, you know, we have this
huddle in the morning. It's 9:00 a.m.
The whole team is on and it's every
department and everyone's coming in.
We're like, "Okay, this is what we need
to do today. We're going to do a popup
distribution outside of our own parking
lot at Babyto Baby and we're going to
serve families with here are the top
needed items and it's diapers, formula,
baby food and people are coming through
and they're driving through and we're
putting everything in. We're also
sending to these shelters that are
already, you know, housing people who
have lost everything and we're making
sure those shelters have everything they
need because what we know is in these
emergencies and in disasters, adults are
really sort of the ones that people
focus on and we're there to focus on the
babies and children. So, if you have
lost your home and you're in a shelter
and you're a parent, there's no crib,
there's no diaper, there's no formula,
there's not a toy, not a book, there's
nothing. So imagine being in that moment
and being a mom or dad and being like,
"Okay, but what about my kid? What am I
doing?" So we are there to provide those
items. And so it's sort of like we have
62 members of our team. We're like,
"Okay, we're all going to break up.
We're all going to conquer this and
we're going to handle it." And so we did
popups around the city. We were sending
truckloads of items. And then we had our
thousand partners sending in requests
saying, "Okay, like this is what we need
in this moment." And what we always do
at Babyto Baby is we ask and listen.
Like we survey people four times a year,
all of these partners that we're talking
about. And in those moments, we're
asking what is needed. Not just
imagining what people might need, but
making sure we're asking and listening.
We had this incredible out outpouring of
support from the community and our
corporate partners are our lifeline. and
they they were um donating millions of
items from hygiene items to diaper bags
and clothes and just people were being

so so generous.
 Yeah. Okay. So, let's
let's go back 14 years.
Very few people know what babyto baby is
14 years ago. How how did the two of you
come in to lead the organization? Uh,
well, I was a model and I lived in New
York and Norah was a lawyer and lived in
New York. And in fact, I hate to give
him credit, but I will. Um, my
father-in-law introduced us.

It set the two of you up.
 Yes, he set
the two of us up because we'd both moved
from New York to LA and we went to
dinner and we were talking about like
our next phase in life and what we
wanted to do. When during my time
modeling, when I was in New York and not
traveling, I was um volunteering at a
Head Start center in Harlem where I got
to spend time with so many children who
couldn't really even focus on their
schoolwork or do any of their school
work without basic essentials. So,
there'd be a little boy there with shoes
that were three sizes too small and he
couldn't do his math worksheet or, you
know, kids that hadn't eaten breakfast.
So, they weren't able to focus on
school. And it was sort of this thing
that like inspired me. I want to work
with kids. I want to do something to
help. And Nora had a similar sort of
situation when she was a lawyer working
with um you know children and mothers
and proono work that she was able to do.
So we sort of met and bonded over this.
It didn't happen right away but we were
like maybe we should start something.
And um we started meeting with
nonprofits in LA to sort of see what the
need was like what was missing. We
didn't want to start something to start
something. Um and we wanted to see like
what was what was really missing. And
everywhere we went we were so shocked.
It was like you know what we don't have
you know what we're doing these services
we aren't able to provide diapers. And
everyone kept saying diapers diapers.
And we were like what diapers? That's so
interesting. Now, we know that like one
in two families in America are
struggling to afford diapers for their
children. People are choosing between
food and diapers for their babies. But
at that moment, we really didn't know.
And it was so interesting learning from
a children's hospital, a homeless
shelter, a domestic violence shelter, a
school. And it was all across the board.
It was the same answer. So, it was this
kind of, you know, question that we
asked that we kept hearing the same
answer for. and we're like, let we can
do something about this. Like, what are
we going to do about this? Let's solve

this.
 So, it's it's one thing to say,
okay, we we've we we like each other. We
have a shared um mission here to then go
and meet and gather the data and
identify, you know, sort of this core
problem and and decide to do something
about That's another thing to say we're
going to be co-CEOs of an organization
and we're going to build something that
that that has the potential to scale to
national and potentially even global
impact. So what what was the inflection
point where you said this actually has
to be a thing, right? That we can't just
do this by going to our friends and
raising some money and maybe talking to,
you know, a big CPG company and getting
some diapers donated. So what what what

was the flip point?
 It kind of is what
we did. uh sort of worked out that way.
So we basically it was the two of us and
we had one intern and we were sitting in
this like 600 square foot like tiny
space on Pico Boulevard and collecting
gently used items from the community.
Maybe you'd uh your baby would outgrow
the size two diapers and you might drop
off like one or two packs. And that was
sort of like the beginning of it all.
And we were sitting there and we were
like, let's like announce that baby to
baby is, you know, the two of us and
we're doing something and we like see a
vision for it. So, we've like scraped
together a little event and asked a
friend to donate alcohol, found a free
space. We had a publicist friend who got
a photographer and we had an event and
it was 20 women and um luckily we had
invited Jessica Alba and Nicole Richie

um and they ended up coming
 as one does.
We do live in LA. I don't know. Um so
they came and a photo ran in US Weekly
and it said the babyto baby event. So,
we're sitting in our little 600 foot
space and we got a phone call and it's
Edelman PR and we're like, "Okay, yeah,
hi." And they're like, "Hi, um, we saw
your photo in US Weekly and we'd love to
do an event with you and we'd like to
give you $100,000 and 100,000 diapers."
And we were like, "What?" At that point,
we'd had like $2,000 and two packs of

your diapers. Maybe you dropped out.
 And
we were like, "Okay, this Yeah, we'd
love to do an event with you." Sure.
They're like, "Can you just repeat what
you did?" And we're like, "Yeah, great.
We'll do it." So, um, they're asking us
like, "Do you accept pallets?" And we're
like, "Yes." And we're like, "What is a
pallet?" Like googling, "What is a
pallet?" And then they're like, "Do you
have forklifts?" And we're like, "Of
course, we have so many forklifts." And
we're like, "How do you rent a
forklift?" And we just sort of started,
you know, we were saying yes to
everything. And we had this event. We
got the $100,000.
The truck showed up, the biggest truck
we've ever seen. We were in heels just
like this and we got on it with our
intern, unloaded ourselves without a

forklift. No forklift.
 No forklift. We
did not have one. Still, we didn't rent

one either.
 And um we unloaded them. The
truck driver was really nice. Thank god
he helped us. And those diapers flew out

the door
 in one day.
 Wow.
 And it was

like, wow, we're really on to
 How is
that possible? Because you you weren't
scaled at that point. All of a sudden

you have this this
 because when the need
is that dramatic, people show up. So we
made a few calls. We called a few
homeless shelters we had known. We
cobbled together a few calls and word
gets out. That's like we're like it was
like gold. We didn't know how this word
spread, but they heard the word diapers
and they needed them and they showed up
in cars and they packed them till they
were totally full and they tied them to
the tops of their cars. And we watch.
It's like if someone needs something and
needs it for their baby, they will drive
far. They came with their friends. They
came after work. They came before work
and word got out and we could have we
could have kept going that people when
there's something valuable, people show

up.
 So I I love this this moment of Yes.
Sure. pallets, forklifts, all of it
because it it's such um every startup,
every entrepreneur knows this feeling of
like oh my god, I just have to say yes.
Like I'll figure it out. I'll build the
airplane on the way down. Um the the
the$100,000 diapers, the $100,000, but
all of a sudden you're you're out of
product and the demand is still there,

right?
 What happens the next day?
I think now we were off. Like this is
kind of I think what binds the two of us
and you hear that, you know, it's not
always the model and the lawyer and that
that doesn't necessarily make sense. But
we've had this vision of um
of making this huge and people, you
know, we would have we'd have very early
interviews of someone saying, "Oh,
what's the goal?" And we'd be like to
provide every child in the world with
diapers and basic essentials. And it was
kind of like that's silly to like that's
not and we were like, "Okay, you can
think that's silly." Like we we had

really big hopes for it.
 Well, maybe

less silly and more audacious.
 Sure.

Yeah.
 Yes. But I think like we just kind
of were like we did the we we didn't
back down from it. We were like we just
gave out 100,000 like great what's next.
When can we double that? Like we just
we're ready. We talked to them and we're
like let's do this again. We need more.
Let's you know like get going. Um, you
know, we had to make some key decisions
quickly, which gets to the point of
scaling and what we were saying before
about how we weren't serving individuals
because I think we realized quickly we
could have given out if there had been a
line of people who needed the diapers
themselves, it would have been much more

complicated.
 Yeah.
 Because there was no
way to we weren't going to ever decide
who gets what and how many and what
size. And we knew if we really wanted to
serve the numbers we wanted to serve, we
had to have a layer in between where one
group could say, you know, that we had
established this group is picking up for
eight children. This group is picking up
for we're shipping diapers to this
person for 120,000 children. And that
was a key decision early because we were
like, if we want to just incrementally
grow, we can just keep having a few
friends in the space and have moms
themselves show up. Like we could have
given out the stuff that way. And it was
like, no, we quickly wanted to go
fast and furious. And we were like, we
have to we are going to have to do this

through organizations.
 Since it began
more than a decade ago, Babyto Baby has
given out 250 million diapers. It's a
number that they are justifiably proud
of, but quick to follow up with this
one. This year alone, they've received
requests for 1.7
billion diapers. That unrelenting need,
that diaper gap drives Kelly and Nora to

keep scaling.
 We started raising the
$100,000 and then raised a little bit
more. We started putting together a
team. Our team has always been
predominantly women and we just put a
lot of smart women together in the room
and kept figuring out the next step.
Some of it happened because of the
celebrity. So sometimes we'd get a phone
call saying,
you know, now there was the next picture
of the next celebrity and the next
celebrity and the next event. And that
helped because that provided for some
incoming phone calls. So we'd get a call
saying um
we h I own a a bottle baby bottle plant
or my friend does and they connected us
to them and we have 126,000 extra baby
bottles. Would you we heard you could do
something with them and again we're like

yes
 yes we lots of room for 12 we can
you know we can take those. We also then
had decisions made based on these things
coming in. Like the plant was in
Philadelphia and we said, "Well,
don't ship them to Los Angeles. I'm sure
there's someone on the East Coast who
could use them and we could use some."
And so this was sort of how we started
serving children outside of Los Angeles.
came from an incoming call where we said
we're getting all of this notoriety from
some of our celebrity relationships
that's giving us press and attention.
But now we can share the wealth. We're
not we don't just have to give out when
we have excess. Let's share it. So
instead of saying let's expand to
Philadelphia today, it was really a call
that started out saying why don't we
look for an organization that does
similar work or could be able to do
similar work in Philadelphia or a
neighboring city. And I'm sure they can
use half those bottles and then why
don't you sell uh ship half of the
bottles to us. So some of our scaling
decisions happened because we get really

good phone calls.
 It sounds like you
effectively built a flywheel. You built
a virtuous cycle where you'd have a
celebrity show up that would get you
some attention that might lead to a
donation. Another Right. Is is that kind

of how it evolved?
 Yeah. part of our
job. We would joke sometimes like we're,
you know, nonprofit CEOs, but we're also
like agents. We're like doing
endorsement deals. That first Huggies
call, we got a h 100,000 diapers and
$100,000. Our next one, we were like,
well, Jen Garner will do it for 5
million diapers and 5 million wipes. And
she did. And now we 14 years later just
got an $8 million grant from Huggies.

Wow.
 In kind and cash. Yeah.
 Why not
Huggies? So, it's sort of like a full
circle moment, but we really did see
like, okay, we can use celebrity to our
benefit. Also, makes the celebrity look
good. Probably their agents and managers
hate us because they don't get the
percentage, but that's fine. Um, and you
know, this corporate partner is happy.
We get to serve children with the basic
essentials that we need for them. And
so, it's sort of like a win-win across
the board. And most corporations do need
a corporate partner and you know want to
for their customers look charitable and

want to do that anyway.
 When wildfires
hit Maui or a hurricane hits Texas or
North Carolina or what have you when
when you're talking about the disasters
that are hitting these other areas where
you don't have infrastructure?
How did you figure out how to serve the

needs there?
 I think we're partnering as
we have from day one with other
nonprofit organizations. So, we are in
there with the Red Cross, with, you
know, World Central Kitchen. We are side
by side. We're popping up if we need to
with our disaster relief team. If the
Red Cross is like, "We've got this, but
we don't have the diapers, formula, and
baby essentials. Can you send them to
us?" Then we're, you know, we're the
person who's providing that. I think
like we're called the Red Cross for kids
which has been a very proud name that
we've taken on but we are that we're
trying to be there to serve the children
in these disasters and however we have
to do it we'll do it. So if we need to
get there with our team and do it
ourselves if there's a partner on the
ground that we work with already that is
like send us the stuff and we can
distribute it we're like great we'll do
it any which way we can. I think like
being spry in these moments is like how
we're able to get to the people and make

sure that everyone is taken care of.
 Um,
so in terms of the scale of the
organization and and uh the annual
budget and and your your prominence,
your profile um just picking up on the
celebrity thread for a moment, can you
talk about the gala and and how you've
built that and how important that is to
to what you all do, the work you all do?
Yeah, I think year one we were like, I
guess we should have a gala. Every
nonprofit has a gala. Let's have a gala.
We raised $1.1 million and we looked at
each other and we were shocked because
in that moment that was so much money.

It's a lot of money.
 A lot of money. Um
where we now raised almost $18 million

this year
 in one night.
 One night.
 In

one night.
 Um and you know the growth of
that has been exciting. But even in that
first year, the same like everything's
still kind of like the same vibe. We
were like, "Okay, let's make sure that
we have an event that is fun that people

want to come to."
 It's not a sit down

rubber chicken.
 No rubber chicken. It's

not in a hotel room.
 No chicken at all.
Just zero chicken. Yeah. And and
nonprofits that have those. We love you
and I'm we are your partner. So great.
Um, but ours is supposed to be, you
know, fun, young, exciting. We have 20
chefs from around Los Angeles who come
and cook at their own station. So, Evan
Funky is making you like Kacio Pepe.
John and Vinnie are making a lobster
roll. Like, just things are happening
and it's fun. Gwennneth Paltro is
feeding you a oyster from found oyster.

I don't know.
 I mean, if I had a nickel
for every time fed me an oyster, I mean,

sure.
 Great. It's the best thing ever.
Um, so we've tried to make it something
that people want to come to, but as much
as people are like, "Oh, it's the
funnest event of the year and you
honored Selma Hayek and Snoop Dog
performed." They're like, "Don't you
have the best time?" We're like, "Nope.
It's work for us. We are there. We are
working. This is where we raise 60% of
our operating budget. We plan it all
year long. those donations that roll in
like the night of that are we do a live
giving on the stage and you know whether
it's Nicole Richie and Mindy Kaling and
they're joking and whatever and we are
sitting there like okay like we we plan
that and it is part of everything that
goes into our 364 days outside of the
gala goes into that night. So it is fun
and it is something people want to come
to. We were proud to be called the
Metall of the West. So that was cool.
Yeah. But um it is work and it is how we
fund serving a million children across
the country every year. So
um the the other angle of your work that
I'm not sure people are as familiar with
is on the policy front. Um we have um
this is not commentary on what's
happening in America today. This is
historically
um uh incredibly uh regressive policies
with regard to maternal health, with
regard to children in need. I I started
my career as a public defender in
Washington DC as representing children
charged as adults and I'll never forget
the first time I walked into a home and
I saw a mom feeding a baby um with a
baby bottle but Coca-Cola and why cuz
it's it's high calorie and it's
inexpensive and if you can't afford
formula like that's what you're going to
do because you're going to feed your kid
one way or another. Um, so could you
share a little bit about how you you
moved into doing policy work and and
what what the focus there has been and
and where you've had some success?
I feel like we're very very specific
about policy work that we get into
because we don't want anything we we're
we're very much um
we pride ourselves on being in a very
narrow lane and I know there's leaders
of nonprofits and for-profits that want
to have as um wider a lane as possible,
but we really have a narrow lane. The
reason we have a narrow lane, as Kelly
mentioned earlier, is that our work is
not done. We've taken on two very
specific instances of advocacy because
they were so um
they were so closely tied to our mission
and our lane. So the first was the
diaper tax. So diapers in many states
are taxed and they are taxed like a
luxury item. And as we always say,
anyone who's ever changed a diaper would
not put diapers in the category. There's
nothing luxurious about changing a dirty
diaper. So they're taxed like things
like diet coke and alcohol and that's
not what they are. They're clearly to
any right-minded person an essential but
for whatever bureaucratic reason from
hundreds of years ago they're classified
as a taxable item.
So that considering diapers are the
number one item we distribute and what
kind of started this entire movement for
us and keeps us up at night. the fact
that diapers are taxed felt like
something we wanted to go fight against.

Y
 So we did that. So again, we didn't
have a road map. We didn't have someone
to ask for advice. We went and we we
started with California because we're
here and we started advocating to remove
the tax in California. We went up to
Sacramento a few times. We brought
celebrities because we were just doing
whatever we could to try to get
attention to get this tax repealed.
And we gave out all the stats about how
one in two families in the United States
are are um struggling to afford diapers.
How diapers are the fourth highest
expenditure in any low-income family's
house after food, rent, utilities, how
people can't drop off their children at
daycare unless they have diapers. So
moms are not going to work and not going
on a job interview because they don't
have diapers. And we explain this all to
uh you know the governor and the and the
politicians in Sacramento.
and we lost a few times and then we flew
back to Los Angeles and then we got
right back up and we went back to
Sacramento. We shifted a little bit and
we kept going and ultimately yeah, Julie
Bowen opened some doors. She was
charming and funny as she is and a few
more people came out to listen to what
we were saying. Um and ultimately uh in
the January of 2020 two 2020
diaper tax was repealed for the first

Um there's and then a bunch of other

states to go. So we continue to be on
that road. But again, we're not pursuing
these options until

you want to talk about
 Yeah.
 maternal

health
 was maternal health. In fact, it
was another phone call, a great one from
the White House and the Biden
administration and they were looking to
um do a pilot in maternal health and
asked babyto baby to join them. So, we
picked um along with them the three

mortality, piloted that program. Kla
Harris came to announce the partnership
at babyto baby headquarters and since
then we have we were that was three
states we're now in 15 states with with
Huggy's help and support but it's
something that we're doing because
obviously the need is there we're seeing
the rates of maternal mortality are
growing especially for black women um
and so it's something that's really
important to us that we see in our work
every day. mental health is now the
number one leading cause of maternal
mortality. And so as soon as that was
brought to our attention and that was,
you know, there's obviously surveys and
a lot of background that goes into this,
we were like, we have to do something
about it, just like we have to do
something about diaper need. And so it's
one of those things that sparked
something in us that is narrow and in
our mission, but something that we know
we can get behind that we can do
something about. And so, you know, we
have a lot of states left to go, but
we're going to get there. Kelly, in
these 15 states where this pilot program
is now expanded to, what's what's
working to um reduce maternal mortality

rates?
 So, we are basically we make
these maternal newborn supply kits. It's
20 items in a kit that you receive right
after you've given birth to a baby. In
those moments, you are obviously
vulnerable in so many ways. But if you
don't have basic supplies to take care
of yourself and to take care of your
baby, then imagine the hopelessness that

you feel
 and the hopelessness that you
feel because you need to take care of
this tiny person and you don't have
those basic essentials to do it. So that
is what we're doing. We're giving moms
in that moment these supplies. And it's
not only diapers and clothes and all the
things that you need for your newborn
baby, but it's things to take care of
yourself because that is also important
in those moments. Plus, it's materials
to, you know, make sure that you know to
keep your health as like a number one
priority in that moment because you
can't take care of your baby if you're
not healthy. So there's a lot of
information inside, not only teaching
you about those 20 supplies and how to
use them for you and your baby, but also
in the case of you might be in some sort
of health situation where you need help
and you need a doctor, there are exactly
those instructions also included. And I
think we we don't, you know, pretend to
be solving the maternal mortality
crisis, which has so many sides to it,
but we do feel like we're a real part of
it now. Um, mental health has now been
cited as the leading cause of maternal
mortality and getting these items to a
mom at this time
has been shown to help her mental
health. So, helping the mental health
aspect, helping her as an all-around new
mom is then leading to greater maternal
health, greater newborn health, and
playing our part in the maternal
mortality crisis. It just strikes me
that, and forgive me for like trying to
be logical here, but so much of what
we're talking about, whether it's a 20
item kit that's going home with a new
mom along with, you know, sort of tips
and guidelines, what have you, or it's
just simply saying like, hey, if if a
mom's going to be able to go to work or
job interview, she's going to be able to
drop her kid at at daycare or at a
relative's house even with diapers. We
need to make sure that they have access
to diapers. that these are relatively
small dollars invested for potential
massive returns, right? In in every
respect in terms of healthier families
and communities, in terms of, you know,
more productive members of society, all
of it.
What is stopping us from from solving
this? Is is it the will? Is it the the
broad understanding that we can do it?
Why can't we get to a point where where
we don't need a baby to baby because we
have fixed these problems? I feel like
we spend so little time with that
question intentionally.
The problems exist and we are
solutionoriented and we need to work
side byside partners. We of course need
the government and uh the for-profit
sector to work alongside us. But I think
our thought is while other people figure
out why that's not being solved, we're
going to do our part to solve it as much
as we can without that help because it

it's not going away.
 We're running short
on time, so I want to I want to bring us
to a close with a handful of sort of
rapid fire just just quick quick
questions for you. Um, what is one great
thing about having a co-CEO? Well, I
call Nora my lawyer face because there's
many things that I do that might be
good, but I'm we may have gotten sued or
taken down if it was for me, if it
wasn't for her because Nora makes sure
to dot the eyes and cross the tees and
make sure that we're always, you know,
keeping everything on point. And so, I
appreciate that as a person who maybe
isn't that way. So I think the yin and
the yang of us has really benefited baby
to baby and our partnership wouldn't
have been possible without like our
different personalities but our
different personalities bring such
different things but the combined
like the combination of the two of us

brings everything to baby to baby.
 One
piece of advice you would give to an
entrepreneur again for-profit not for
profofit doesn't matter who's identified
a problem and wants to go solve it. I
think we've said it a million times, but
saying yes really worked in our benefit
and we said yes a lot in the beginning
and we had a lot of incoming support but
we said yes every time and then just
figured it out and that's really how we

grew in the beginning
 and then we
started saying no

showing its face right now.
 So we did
say yes for a long time. We I we still
believe in the power of yes, but there
are some very difficult times where you
have to say no. I think we have we've
had to say no when our donors wanted to
keep giving us gently used things and we
realized that is expensive and not
scalable and that someone should do that
but that can't be this organization
where we're reaching so many people. I
think in a in a disaster when someone
wants to drop off beautiful puzzles and
we have to say right now if you give us
puzzles we can't get out this water
quickly enough and so we have had to
learn in the very hard way because we're
so
used to saying yes that you do also have
to sometimes say no. Um,
one thing that the hundreds of people
here tonight and the hundreds of
thousands of people who will listen to
or watch this um when we release this

can do to support your mission.
 So many
things. Um, no, you can I think a lot of
our updates are on our social media. So
our Instagram is babytobaby with the
number two. Um, our website is
babytobaby.org. But I think not only is
it donating funds because of course
every nonprofit needs funds, but we do
love volunteers coming in and helping as
we said like our maternal newborn supply
kits are packed purely by volunteers. So
when I'm telling you that they are going
out to 15 states now that new moms are
receiving these every day that is
because of our volunteer force. I think
besides that corporate partners have
been a huge part of how we have grown
and these donations of corporate you
know it's bottles it's formula it's
diapers but it's also socks and shoes
and clothes and these have really been a
feel like allowed us to distribute half
a billion items since we have started.
So that is really a number one thing.
These corporate partnerships and inind
donations really go a long way for the

children we serve.
 And just to add, it
sounds cliche, but the idea that in
helping us that there's no donation too
small is really true. And I think we
almost suffer from a reputation that
comes along with our celebrity
supporters that we don't need help or we
only need help on such a massive scale.
And so that someone sitting in the
audience or with a company that doesn't
have $8 million or 8 million diapers
that there's no place for them. But it
it it's really not true. And it's the
you know it's the 40,000 donors that
that gave to our fire fund that allowed
us to give out the 20 million items in
the fires. And it's all of the people
that came together. It's not I mean yes
you know if Beyonce wants to be honored
at our gala we will welcome her and we
will you know and we will take everyone
everyone Coca-Cola and American Express
and Skims will take the biggest

companies there are supporting us
 but we
will but you know a donation of
books or shoes or a company with
any item and any amount of funds it
really does add up and it has led to um
where we are today. Yeah, I I I I love
that as a place to to bring us to a
close that there is is no you you have
no idea the impact that every small
action can have. Um on behalf of Los
Angeles, on behalf of every community
that Babyto Baby serves, thank you for
the work you do. Thanks for being with

us tonight for joining us.
 Thank you.
Thank you.
From a scrappy start that nearly every
entrepreneur can identify with, Babyto
Baby has evolved into renowned not for-p
profofit with an enormous impact.
Norris and Kelly's story is a valuable
reminder that the most essential
ingredient for scaling your idea is an
unwavering belief that the problem you
target is worth solving. And
notwithstanding the extraordinary scale
that Kelly and Norah have reached, there
is so much more to do. Special thanks to
our event team and the team at Neya
House in Los Angeles.
I'm Jeff Berman. Thank you for
listening.

cleanText:
[Music]
[Music]
Hey folks, Jeff Berman here. This week we're sharing my conversation with the incredibly impressive co-CEOs of the not-for-profit Baby2Baby. From day one of the devastating wildfires in Los Angeles at the start of the year, Baby2Baby was on the ground providing essential items to families in dire need. Disaster relief is just part of the support that Baby2Baby provides under Norah Weinstein and Kelly Sawyer Patricof's leadership. In partnership with not-for-profits around the country, they've now distributed more than 250 million diapers and they now serve over a million families across the United States each and every year. We gathered recently for a Masters of Scale live event in Los Angeles presented by our partners at Capital One Business to talk about how Kelly and Nora have scaled Baby2Baby and what it was like to face a disaster in their home town. This is Masters of Scale.

Kelly, Nora, welcome to Masters of Scale. I can't imagine a more fitting and important conversation for us to have um on this stage in LA. Um, uh, I've been here for 20 years in LA. It's home for me. Um, and the fires that we had at the top of the year were devastating for I'm sure everyone in the room if you weren't personally affected, someone you could love, some member of your family, um, lost their home, lost their business, lost their community. Um, and so I want to take us back to January 7th. Um, where where was each of you when you when you first heard about the fires? Where were you?

You know, it the news obviously started unfolding slowly. So it was I was talking to colleagues. I had friends calling. I live in Brentwood. So I had like my first batch of Palisades people texting me. Then we were some not you know it was kind of slowly trickling in. And um, it you know we've Baby2Baby has now responded to a hundred disasters but this one was different because this was our backyard. It was our home. So, while we're used to saying, "Okay, everyone, we're having a huddle, there's a hurricane, or this is hitting Texas or this is happening in Florida, this was um the manager of our warehouse has now just been evacuated, or I was figuring out where my kids were in school and finding out what was happening." So, it was so personal from the get-go. And you we had to kind of juggle dealing with the personal and dealing with the professional, which was our jobs in this moment were to take what we had learned in 14 years and apply it where we're looking out for children and families in disasters and apply all the lessons we've learned into this moment where it probably mattered the most.

Kelly, where were you? I was sadly in bed with the flu and you know, we're watching each of our employees be evacuated. One of our employees lost their home. Their sister lost their home. They evacuated with their children with just the clothes on their back. So, we were really in it in a way we'd never been in it before. That felt so different to us and personal to us because all around us, not only friends were losing their homes, but also our staff who we care so much about. And what was so amazing was that the community came together and Baby2Baby became this kind of like hub of like what can we do? How can we help? We've never had like volunteer sessions so full people like beating down our doors to come and there were hundreds of people multiple times a day coming and wanting to help. And many of the people who came had lost their own homes and they just you know would cry and say like I want to do something. I don't know what else to do. I just want to help. And so people are putting together fire relief packages for children and um, you know, families who've lost everything. And it was so scary and sad but also so inspiring to see LA and the community come together in that moment and to have the space to be able to hold that.

So how did you flip from we've got to deal with ourselves and our people to we've got to serve the community. What how did you transition into that mode? I feel like we have seen it before because through our disaster relief work, we're constantly around people in these other cities who are having similar circumstances. We know that we are our team over 14 years has built this expertise and we've built it in 50 states and 300 cities. But in Los Angeles, our team knows this city, every inch of it. And we know where children are and we know where the most vulnerable children are.

How do you know? How how do you know that? I mean, yes, you're you're you're Angelinos, you're staples of this community, you're integrated, but is there data telling you that? Is it because you've got partners? Where's that coming from? Right. It's because 14 years ago when the two of us uh took over the leadership of Baby2Baby and built what what Baby2Baby is today, we started off we we've always been a model where we don't serve families and children directly on a regular basis. We've always known that in order to scale, we had to serve partners, serve their serve clients. So what that means is we've been building for 14 years a network of organizations in Los Angeles and all over the country. So speaking about Los Angeles, we have a program team that is working with hospitals, foster care agencies, homeless shelters, schools, community resource centers, and one by one we onboarded them to serve them on a regular basis. So that we might have a tiny homeless shelter in the valley and they have eight beds and we know that regularly they need supplies for the rotating eight families that might be coming in and out. Then we also serve the entire Los Angeles Unified School District um where we're serving tens of thousands of students who go to school and they're identifying who the students are who are most in need, who are experiencing homelessness, who might be um in foster care, etc. We know which shelters to be looking out for to think, well, that shelter must have burned down, so we need to get to these kids and they probably would have gone here. where we know the principal at this school, so we're gonna know who to contact. So, that's what I mean.

Kelly, um, just staying with January for a moment, um, help us understand the the scope and scale of what the relief efforts required and and the the the size of what Baby2Baby did in in that moment. I think, you know, we have this huddle in the morning. It's 9:00 a.m. The whole team is on and it's every department and everyone's coming in. We're like, "Okay, this is what we need to do today. We're going to do a popup distribution outside of our own parking lot at Baby2Baby and we're going to serve families with here are the top needed items and it's diapers, formula, baby food and people are coming through and they're driving through and we're putting everything in. We're also sending to these shelters that are already, you know, housing people who have lost everything and we're making sure those shelters have everything they need because what we know is in these emergencies and in disasters, adults are really sort of the ones that people focus on and we're there to focus on the babies and children. So, if you have lost your home and you're in a shelter and you're a parent, there's no crib, there's no diaper, there's no formula, there's not a toy, not a book, there's nothing. So imagine being in that moment and being a mom or dad and being like, "Okay, but what about my kid? What am I doing?" So we are there to provide those items. And so it's sort of like we have 62 members of our team. We're like, "Okay, we're all going to break up. We're all going to conquer this and we're going to handle it." And so we did popups around the city. We were sending truckloads of items. And then we had our thousand partners sending in requests saying, "Okay, like this is what we need in this moment." And what we always do at Baby2Baby is we ask and listen. Like we survey people four times a year, all of these partners that we're talking about. And in those moments, we're asking what is needed. Not just imagining what people might need, but making sure we're asking and listening. We had this incredible outpouring of support from the community and our corporate partners are our lifeline. and they they were um donating millions of items from hygiene items to diaper bags and clothes and just people were being so so generous.

Yeah. Okay. So, let's let's go back 14 years. Very few people know what Baby2Baby is 14 years ago. How how did the two of you come in to lead the organization? Uh, well, I was a model and I lived in New York and Norah was a lawyer and lived in New York. And in fact, I hate to give him credit, but I will. Um, my father-in-law introduced us.

It set the two of you up. Yes, he set the two of us up because we'd both moved from New York to LA and we went to dinner and we were talking about like our next phase in life and what we wanted to do. When during my time modeling, when I was in New York and not traveling, I was um volunteering at a Head Start center in Harlem where I got to spend time with so many children who couldn't really even focus on their schoolwork or do any of their school work without basic essentials. So, there'd be a little boy there with shoes that were three sizes too small and he couldn't do his math worksheet or, you know, kids that hadn't eaten breakfast. So, they weren't able to focus on school. And it was sort of this thing that like inspired me. I want to work with kids. I want to do something to help. And Nora had a similar sort of situation when she was a lawyer working with um, you know, children and mothers and pro bono work that she was able to do. So we sort of met and bonded over this. It didn't happen right away but we were like maybe we should start something. And um, we started meeting with nonprofits in LA to sort of see what the need was like what was missing. We didn't want to start something to start something. Um, and we wanted to see like what was what was really missing. And everywhere we went we were so shocked. It was like you know what we don't have, you know what we're doing these services, we aren't able to provide diapers. And everyone kept saying diapers, diapers. And we were like, what diapers? That's so interesting. Now, we know that like one in two families in America are struggling to afford diapers for their children. People are choosing between food and diapers for their babies. But at that moment, we really didn't know. And it was so interesting learning from a children's hospital, a homeless shelter, a domestic violence shelter, a school. And it was all across the board. It was the same answer. So, it was this kind of, you know, question that we asked that we kept hearing the same answer for. and we're like, let we can do something about this. Like, what are we going to do about this? Let's solve this.

So, it's it's one thing to say, okay, we we've we we like each other. We have a shared um mission here to then go and meet and gather the data and identify, you know, sort of this core problem and and decide to do something about That's another thing to say we're going to be co-CEOs of an organization and we're going to build something that that that has the potential to scale to national and potentially even global impact. So what what was the inflection point where you said this actually has to be a thing, right? That we can't just do this by going to our friends and raising some money and maybe talking to, you know, a big CPG company and getting some diapers donated. So what what what was the flip point? It kind of is what we did. uh, sort of worked out that way. So we basically it was the two of us and we had one intern and we were sitting in this like 600 square foot like tiny space on Pico Boulevard and collecting gently used items from the community. Maybe you'd uh your baby would outgrow the size two diapers and you might drop off like one or two packs. And that was sort of like the beginning of it all. And we were sitting there and we were like, let's like announce that Baby2Baby is, you know, the two of us and we're doing something and we like see a vision for it. So, we've like scraped together a little event and asked a friend to donate alcohol, found a free space. We had a publicist friend who got a photographer and we had an event and it was 20 women and um luckily we had invited Jessica Alba and Nicole Richie um and they ended up coming as one does. We do live in LA. I don't know. Um so they came and a photo ran in US Weekly and it said the Baby2Baby event. So, we're sitting in our little 600 foot space and we got a phone call and it's Edelman PR and we're like, "Okay, yeah, hi." And they're like, "Hi, um, we saw your photo in US Weekly and we'd love to do an event with you and we'd like to give you $100,000 and 100,000 diapers." And we were like, "What?" At that point, we'd had like $2,000 and two packs of your diapers. Maybe you dropped out. And we were like, "Okay, this Yeah, we'd love to do an event with you." Sure. They're like, "Can you just repeat what you did?" And we're like, "Yeah, great. We'll do it." So, um, they're asking us like, "Do you accept pallets?" And we're like, "Yes." And we're like, "What is a pallet?" Like googling, "What is a pallet?" And then they're like, "Do you have forklifts?" And we're like, "Of course, we have so many forklifts." And we're like, "How do you rent a forklift?" And we just sort of started, you know, we were saying yes to everything. And we had this event. We got the $100,000. The truck showed up, the biggest truck we've ever seen. We were in heels just like this and we got on it with our intern, unloaded ourselves without a forklift.

No forklift. No forklift. We did not have one. Still, we didn't rent one either. And, um, we unloaded them. The truck driver was really nice. Thank God he helped us. And those diapers flew out the door in one day. Wow. And it was like, wow, we're really on to... How is that possible? Because you, you weren't scaled at that point. All of a sudden, you have this, this... Because when the need is that dramatic, people show up. So we made a few calls. We called a few homeless shelters we had known. We cobbled together a few calls and word gets out. That's like, we're like, it was like gold. We didn't know how this word spread, but they heard the word diapers and they needed them and they showed up in cars and they packed them till they were totally full and they tied them to the tops of their cars. And we watch. It's like if someone needs something and needs it for their baby, they will drive far. They came with their friends. They came after work. They came before work and word got out and we could have, we could have kept going. That people, when there's something valuable, people show up. So I, I love this, this moment of, yes, sure, pallets, forklifts, all of it because it, it's such, um, every startup, every entrepreneur knows this feeling of like, oh my God, I just have to say yes. Like, I'll figure it out. I'll build the airplane on the way down. Um, the, the, the $100,000 diapers, the $100,000, but all of a sudden you're, you're out of product and the demand is still there, right? What happens the next day? I think now we were off. Like, this is kind of, I think what binds the two of us and you hear that, you know, it's not always the model and the lawyer and that, that doesn't necessarily make sense. But we've had this vision of, um, of making this huge and people, you know, we would have, we'd have very early interviews of someone saying, "Oh, what's the goal?" And we'd be like, "To provide every child in the world with diapers and basic essentials." And it was kind of like, that's silly. To like, that's not... And we were like, "Okay, you can think that's silly." Like, we, we had really big hopes for it. Well, maybe less silly and more audacious. Sure. Yeah. Yes. But I think like we just kind of were like, we did the, we, we didn't back down from it. We were like, we just gave out 100,000. Like, great, what's next? When can we double that? Like, we just, we're ready. We talked to them and we're like, let's do this again. We need more. Let's, you know, like, get going. Um, you know, we had to make some key decisions quickly, which gets to the point of scaling and what we were saying before about how we weren't serving individuals because I think we realized quickly we could have given out if there had been a line of people who needed the diapers themselves, it would have been much more complicated. Yeah. Because there was no way to, we weren't going to ever decide who gets what and how many and what size. And we knew if we really wanted to serve the numbers we wanted to serve, we had to have a layer in between where one group could say, you know, that we had established this group is picking up for eight children. This group is picking up for, we're shipping diapers to this person for 120,000 children. And that was a key decision early because we were like, if we want to just incrementally grow, we can just keep having a few friends in the space and have moms themselves show up. Like, we could have given out the stuff that way. And it was like, no, we quickly wanted to go fast and furious. And we were like, we have to, we are going to have to do this through organizations. Since it began more than a decade ago, Baby2Baby has given out 250 million diapers. It's a number that they are justifiably proud of, but quick to follow up with this one. This year alone, they've received requests for 1.7 billion diapers. That unrelenting need, that diaper gap drives Kelly and Norah to keep scaling. We started raising the $100,000 and then raised a little bit more. We started putting together a team. Our team has always been predominantly women and we just put a lot of smart women together in the room and kept figuring out the next step. Some of it happened because of the celebrity. So sometimes we'd get a phone call saying, you know, now there was the next picture of the next celebrity and the next celebrity and the next event. And that helped because that provided for some incoming phone calls. So we'd get a call saying, um, "We, I own a, a bottle, baby bottle plant or my friend does and they connected us to them and we have 126,000 extra baby bottles. Would you, we heard you could do something with them?" And again, we're like, "Yes." Yes, we, lots of room for 12. We can, you know, we can take those. We also then had decisions made based on these things coming in. Like the plant was in Philadelphia and we said, "Well, don't ship them to Los Angeles. I'm sure there's someone on the East Coast who could use them and we could use some." And so this was sort of how we started serving children outside of Los Angeles. Came from an incoming call where we said, we're getting all of this notoriety from some of our celebrity relationships that's giving us press and attention. But now we can share the wealth. We're not, we don't just have to give out when we have excess. Let's share it. So instead of saying, let's expand to Philadelphia today, it was really a call that started out saying, why don't we look for an organization that does similar work or could be able to do similar work in Philadelphia or a neighboring city? And I'm sure they can use half those bottles and then why don't you sell, uh, ship half of the bottles to us. So some of our scaling decisions happened because we get really good phone calls. It sounds like you effectively built a flywheel. You built a virtuous cycle where you'd have a celebrity show up that would get you some attention that might lead to a donation. Another, right? Is is that kind of how it evolved? Yeah. Part of our job. We would joke sometimes like we're, you know, nonprofit CEOs, but we're also like agents. We're like doing endorsement deals. That first Huggies call, we got a, a 100,000 diapers and $100,000. Our next one, we were like, well, Jen Garner will do it for 5 million diapers and 5 million wipes. And she did. And now we, 14 years later, just got an $8 million grant from Huggies. Wow. In kind and cash. Yeah. Why not Huggies? So, it's sort of like a full circle moment, but we really did see like, okay, we can use celebrity to our benefit. Also makes the celebrity look good. Probably their agents and managers hate us because they don't get the percentage, but that's fine. Um, and, you know, this corporate partner is happy. We get to serve children with the basic essentials that we need for them. And so, it's sort of like a win-win across the board. And most corporations do need a corporate partner and you know, want to for their customers look charitable and want to do that anyway. When wildfires hit Maui or a hurricane hits Texas or North Carolina or what have you, when, when you're talking about the disasters that are hitting these other areas where you don't have infrastructure? How did you figure out how to serve the needs there? I think we're partnering, as we have from day one, with other nonprofit organizations. So, we are in there with the Red Cross, with, you know, World Central Kitchen. We are side by side. We're popping up if we need to with our disaster relief team. If the Red Cross is like, "We've got this, but we don't have the diapers, formula, and baby essentials. Can you send them to us?" Then we're, you know, we're the person who's providing that. I think like we're called the Red Cross for kids, which has been a very proud name that we've taken on, but we are that. And I know there's leaders of nonprofits and for-profits that want to have as, um, wider a lane as possible, but we really have a narrow lane. The reason we have a narrow lane, as Kelly mentioned earlier, is that our work is not done. We've taken on two very specific instances of advocacy because they were so, um, they were so closely tied to our mission and our lane. So the first was the diaper tax. So diapers in many states are taxed and they are taxed like a luxury item. And as we always say, anyone who's ever changed a diaper would not put diapers in the category. There's nothing luxurious about changing a dirty diaper. So they're taxed like things like Diet Coke and alcohol and that's not what they are. They're clearly, to any right-minded person, an essential. But for whatever bureaucratic reason from hundreds of years ago, they're classified as a taxable item. We went and we, we started with California because we're here and we started advocating to remove the tax in California. We went up to Sacramento a few times. We brought celebrities because we were just doing whatever we could to try to get attention to get this tax repealed. And we gave out all the stats about how one in two families in the United States are, are, um, struggling to afford diapers. How diapers are the fourth highest expenditure in any low-income family's house after food, rent, utilities. How people can't drop off their children at daycare unless they have diapers. times, and then we flew back to Los Angeles. And then we got right back up, and we went back to Sacramento. We shifted a little bit, and we kept going. It's 20 items in a kit that you receive right after you've given birth to a baby. In those moments, you are obviously vulnerable in so many ways. But if you don't have basic supplies to take care of yourself and to take care of your baby, then imagine the hopelessness that you feel and the hopelessness that you feel because you need to take care of this tiny person, and you don't have those basic essentials to do it. So that is what we're doing. We're giving moms in that moment these supplies. And it's not only diapers and clothes and all the things that you need for your newborn baby, but it's things to take care of yourself because that is also important in those moments.
